citations.narrative:
The facility has not yet worked on developing a contingency plan since the last inspection. A contingency plan is required
to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing and care of the animals in the event of an
emergency or disaster. The plan should identify the situations triggering the plan, outline the tasks to be carried out,
identify a chain of command, and address how the response and recovery will be handled. The optional APHIS form left
at the facility at the last inspection is empty and no other document has been started. The facility shall develop and
document a detailed contingency plan.

Ten small recently weaned rabbits are currently housed in an enclosure 20inx36in (providing 5 square feet). Once
weaned, each rabbit weighing less than 4.4 lbs. needs to have 1.5 square feet of space. Thus if an enclosure houses all
ten rabbits it should supply 15 square feet of floor space. Adequate floor space is necessary to allow the rabbits to make
normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement. Each rabbit weighing less than 4.4lbs shall
be provided with 1.5 square feet of space. Correct by 3/29/23.

The current enclosure housing the two coatimundi is not enclosed by a perimeter fence at least six feet in height and
three feet in distance from the primary enclosure fence. Since the last inspection, the facility has added a perimeter fence
for the kangaroo and wallaby. A perimeter fence is necessary to keep out unauthorized animals and persons and to act as
a secondary containment fence if the animals were to get out. The facility shall build a secondary or perimeter fence for
the exotic species owned at least six feet in height and three feet in distance from the primary enclosure.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.134(a)  Repeat
   
Contingency planning. 
The facility has not yet worked on developing a contingency plan since the last inspection. A contingency plan is required 
to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing and care of the animals in the event of an 
emergency or disaster. The plan should identify the situations triggering the plan, outline the tasks to be carried out, 
identify a chain of command, and address how the response and recovery will be handled. The optional APHIS form left 
at the facility at the last inspection is empty and no other document has been started. The facility shall develop and 
document a detailed contingency plan. 
3.53(c)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Ten small recently weaned rabbits are currently housed in an enclosure 20inx36in (providing 5 square feet). Once 
weaned, each rabbit weighing less than 4.4 lbs. needs to have 1.5 square feet of space. Thus if an enclosure houses all 
ten rabbits it should supply 15 square feet of floor space. Adequate floor space is necessary to allow the rabbits to make 
normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement. Each rabbit weighing less than 4.4lbs shall 
be provided with 1.5 square feet of space. Correct by 3/29/23. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor.

The current enclosure housing the two coatimundi is not enclosed by a perimeter fence at least six feet in height and 
three feet in distance from the primary enclosure fence. Since the last inspection, the facility has added a perimeter fence 
for the kangaroo and wallaby. A perimeter fence is necessary to keep out unauthorized animals and persons and to act as 
a secondary containment fence if the animals were to get out. The facility shall build a secondary or perimeter fence for 
the exotic species owned at least six feet in height and three feet in distance from the primary enclosure. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
